conbody.p: As mentioned, most modern web frameworks have some kind of routing system. For contrast, let's take a quick example from Django:urlpatterns = patterns('', (r'^articles/2003/$', 'news.views.special_case_2003'), (r'^articles/(\d{4})/$', 'news.views.year_archive'), (r'^articles/(\d{4})/(\d{2})/$', 'news.views.month_archive'), (r'^articles/(\d{4})/(\d{2})/(\d+)/$', 'news.views.article_detail'), )https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/http/urls/These routes are specified via a regular expression. While this is declarative, the routes are really being resolved by running some extra code. This has some practical ramifications. Firstly, there's no great way to optimize the routing: the only way to determine which route matches is to go through every single regular expression linearly. Yesod's routes are broken down into individual pieces and routed to based on an efficient data structure.

But a more important issue is overlapping. Yesod will stop you from accidently writing two routes that would match the same URL. This fits in with Yesod's overall philosophy of catching as many errors as possible at compile time.
conbody.note: You're probably wondering what the Django example would look like in Yesod. It looks very similar actually:/articles/!2003 News2003R GET /articles/#Year NewsYearR GET /articles/#Year/#Month NewsMonthR GET /articles/#Year/#Month/#ArticleId NewsArticleR GETBut if you notice, the first two routes overlap! By adding the exclamation point in front of the 2003, you can tell Yesod to ignore the overlapping for this route.
